With respect to Mr. Attwell’s argument that the case is really based on Section 7(e) not 7(b) because Gulf was not able and willing to initiate the service, there are several answers to that.One is that it contradicts the certificates; the certificates granted to Gulf said precisely that Gulf is able and willing to perform the service and these certificates were limited, were unlimited at time, not limited to the 50 years of the lease.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Then Mr. Barnett, do you agree that if the Commission is right, Gulf may remain in the picture permanently until the will expires.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Not permanently, we will not take to Gulf-

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: -—the well is exhausted there?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: No, we do not take the position that the Commission could make Gulf sell Southland’s gas permanently.
The Commission held that Gulf must seek abandonment.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Yes, I know but they would have power to deny the petition for abandonment as long as there was still gas available in the well, would they not?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Well, so long as they also have power to deny Southland --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Correct, but surely if they have the power over Southland, it would follow a fortiori would it not, that they could keep Gulf in the picture.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Yes, so long as Southland is there but we do not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why do you say that Mr. Barnett, cannot the lessor at least Illinois has to stay in the interstate market at least get rid of his lessee?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Well, I think that is true too that the Commission could—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, it cannot be both ways.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Well someone else could be a substituted for Gulf I suppose.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Substitute—

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Someone like whom?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: One of the lessors since I would hold, when the lessee’s expired, I understand that I have to stay in the interstate market but I do want to deal with Gulf anymore.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Well, in that case, that is what I have in mind by saying the lessor could bring in someone other than Gulf to—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about itself, Southland?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: I think Southland itself could—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If it were equipped.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Yes, I think Southland itself could be substituted for Gulf if necessary.
The point is that Southland ultimately is the natural gas company by virtue of having succeeded to this dedicated service in natural gas.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But if Southland is a bunch of doctors sitting in Los Angeles, they are not going want to start building a pipeline themselves.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Well you do not have to build a pipeline to be a seller of Natural Gas Mr. Justice Rehnquist, there are many owners of producing interest who have no facilities in the sense of pipes or anything but which our natural gas companies under the Act because they are engaged in sales of natural gas.
Indeed we would say the reserve itself is the facility if you need a facility.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: One the last day of the 50th year, Mr. Barnett, why is any petition for abandonment necessary?
What does Gulf have to abandon?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Gulf has a continuing service which is still performing and as the Commission said—

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But when it performed anything under a lease after it has expired?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Well, all the Commission said was that we are requiring Gulf to seek abandonment so that we will have all the parties before us if we have to rearrange their legal arrangements, it is really a sort of—

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Could they order Southland to make a new lease with Gulf?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: They could order Southland to make a lease with somebody to continue selling.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then you are, you have answered your-- I am sure it is not intentional this when you have given contradictory answers to Justice White and to Justice Stevens.
Did you say that the Commission can rearrange the legal arrangements of the parties; that is a rather strange notion to emanate from the Statute is it not?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Well, to make clear that Southland is required to continue this service which Gulf has begun under the lease.

The Commission said we have, we need all the parties before us if we are going to, I think it said rearrange, resettle their legal arrangements but the point is that Southland contends that it does not have to sell this gas in the interstate commerce, the Commission would be telling it that it does, that is a rearrangement of the legal arrangement at least to Southland view as it was.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But do you take the position Mr. Barnett that by virtue of Gulf’s dedication, the commission acquired greater power over Southland that it has over gulf?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Well, in the sense that after the 50 years it now has power to require Gulf, to require Southland to sell the gas—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does it also have power to require Gulf to stay in the picture, assuming you are right on Southland—?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: To stay in the picture—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: As lessee—

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: I do not, not if Southland wants another lessee, but if Gulf is being in the picture is necessary to effectuate --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It does not have the power to deny the Petition for Abandonment even though the source or supply remains available, that is your position.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: No, it has the power to deny the petition for Gulf’s abandonment or to require Gulf the files that you petitioned as it did here—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: —if its act on it, can it deny it, that is my question.
Does the Commission have the power to A, hold that Southland’s gas must remain available and B, we are going to deny Gulf’s petition for abandonment, does it have such power?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if Southland says we are not going to do anything at all, we are tired of this business, we are just going to let the gas stay where it is, we would not want to make a new lease with anybody?
Can the Commission say, here are three names, make a list with one of them?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Yes, in the United Gas Pipeline case, the Commission required the pipeline to keep purchasing in the Sunray case, it required the seller to keep selling, that would be the same thing here.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you would not think you could or do you?
I do not know what your answer is now.
May the Commission keep deny Gulf’s Petition for Abandonment and make it stay in the picture over Southland’s objection.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Not if Southland has someone else it wants in the picture instead of Gulf.
But if Southland does not have someone else, if Southland’s objection is based on not wanting this gas to be sold to interstate commerce—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well I suppose that there is one reason for requiring a lessee under an expiring lease to file is just at least to make sure that the lease is expiring and it is not just a trumped up arrangement.

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: Well, that may be one reason, yes.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, there would not be much difficultly about that, the Commission’s record show the lease—

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: The present record as I understand do not show the lease and this case was brought by Declaratory Judgment Action before the Commission.
I think ordinarily the Commission would not be aware that a particular lease is expired.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You mean because that is 50 years ago but they certainly must keep records these days do they not?

turn.speaker: stephen_r_barnett
turn.label: Mr. Stephen R. Barnett
turn.text: It is my understanding that they do not keep records of leases, I could be wrong but that is my understanding.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentleman.
The case is submitted.
